text: Let's go to your house.
I don’t want to go to my house.
Where do you want to go then?
I don't know. Someplace else. Maria gazes up at the top of the building and smiles.
How about up there?
(looks up) On the roof? Why do you wanna go up there?
Why not? ... Come on. It’s not that high.
What are you crazy? (CONTINUED)
(fixes him) See how you treat me? You’re a drag.
Let’s not get started with this, OK?
If I go up there will you follow me?

(reticent) If I go, are we gonna do it up there? Maria smiles. She turns and takes a good look at the back the building. She puts her foot on a rock and pulls herse up to a first-floor window-sill. She finds a small ledge continues to scale up. Juan looks sure she won’t make it up. Maria concentrates what she's doing - never looking down. She pulls herself up to a second-floor window, but then g stuck about six feet below the roof.

Come down. We’ll go to your place. Maria places her foot on a very small protrusion and push up - she SLIPS but grabs the edge of the roof just in tim and pulls herself up. Juan stares up in disbelief.
(smiles, looking down) Come on. Your turn.
No way.
Come up - I have something to tell you.
Come down.
No. Beat. Juan looks around, at a loss for what to do.
You know what then, I’m taking off. (CONTINUED)
(exasperated) Then go. I'm not coming down.
Fine. You can come down the same way you went up - alone. I’11 see ya. Juan starts to walk away down the hill. Maria watches him go, down toward a small, isolated town ringed by mountains.

INT. BEDROOM — BEFORE DAWN In a small bedroom with lime-green walls and two single b Maria lies ASLEEP with her walkman next to her pillow. On the wall above her are torn-out magazine pictures of vari teen idols, salsa stars, and a pink cartoon teddy-bear. Maria’s mother JUANA calls from the other room,

Maria. Get up. INT. BATHROOM — BEFORE DAWN A precarious electric water-heating element mounted on th shower-head, with wires sticking out of it, shifts into t On position. Maria puts her head fully under the water. INT. KITCHEN / MAIN ROOM — BEFORE DAWN PACHO, one year old, is CRYING on his back on a tattered couch in the main room of the small house. Maria’s sister DIANA, 19, stands over him, pressing down on his stomach. ROSITA, Maria’s grandmother, moves to and from the crampe kitchen setting out cups of hot chocolate and rolls. JUAN 40, is already dressed and folding laundry.
His stomach is hard. I’m really worried. Maria comes in combing her hair.
What are you doing? (CONTINUED)
He hasn’t shit in like two days. He’s really constipated.
Whatever. He’ll go when he goes. Don’t worry about it.
Maria, don’t brush your hair in the dining room please.

He’s cranky because he’s got someone kneading his stomach like a ball of dough. (tickling Pacho) Isn’t that right? Huh? Isn’t that right? Maria picks Pacho up and holds him over her head. him and catches him.
(taking him back) You're scaring him.
Give him to me.
(setting down hot chocolate) Maria, sit. Juana takes the baby and gives Diana a blanket.
Mama, will you fix a tea for him?
Those teas aren’t gonna do anything for him.
Take him to the doctor this afternoon.
No Grandma, I don’t trust that guy.
(gets up) She throws He doesn’t need to go to the doctor. The kid is fine. (CONTINUED)
Maria goes into the kitchen and opens the fridge.
What are you looking for?
I don’t know. I don’t feel like bread. I want something else. Maria cuts a piece of pork sausage for herself.

That's your breakfast? EXT. ROAD — DARK MORNING Maria, Juana and Diana walk along a dark, dusty road befo dawn. The only light comes from the windows of other hous they pass. They turn onto a PAVED STREET and stop at an arbitrary sp on the sidewalk and wait with several other people. There a minimum of ambient morning light; it’s cold, people hud A creaky, old SCHOOL BUS lumbers up and everyone files on except for Maria. Juana kisses Maria’s cheek and gets on.

See you later, honey. The bus pulls away and Maria continues to wait. INT. MOVING BUS (ANOTHER) — VERY EARLY MORNING Maria sits by the window with BLANCA, also 17 but heavier than Maria. The bus lurches along. The seats are full of other people (mostly women), but there is no conversation only the sound of the driver's tinny radio. Blanca has her head on Maria’s shoulder. Maria stares out the passing farmland and cows. EXT. PLANTATION GATEHOUSE — LATER Maria and Blanca get off the bus and merge into a small s of people who funnel through a tall steel gate past a uniformed guard with steel-toed boots and a shotgun. On t other side, the grounds are landscaped and spotless.  INT. CHANGING ROOMS — CONTINUOUS Maria, Blanca and about two dozen other women put on blue jumpsuits over their clothes, along with thick, rubber bo INT. EATING ROOM — CONTINUOUS In a large room with long wooden tables and benches, abou hundred workers eat breakfast. There is a din of conversation. At one table, Blanca eats a roll as Maria interrogates her.
So did you meet him?
I waited by the plaza but he never came.
Are you kidding? He didn't show up?
Well it wasn't a real date. He said he might be there.
(laughing) How long did you wait?
Don't laugh.
I'm not laughing. How long did you wait?

It doesn't matter. He wasn’t really my type... Anyway... You see that guy over there? They both turn and look at a GUY in a green jumpsuit sitt two tables away. He makes eye contact with Blanca and SMI

He smiles at me like all the time. The two of them GIGGLE uncontrollably.  INT. BATHROOM — LATER Maria stands at the basin of the plantation bathroom. She splashes water on her face and rinses her mouth. INT. FLOWER PLANTATION — LATER In a vast greenhouse, rows and rows of tall pink-rose pla extend into the distance. A space-man wearing a thick rub suit, a rubber face mask and a rubber head-covering walks through spraying a fine mist of chemical fumigants onto t flowers. Elsewhere in the same greenhouse women clip rose This is a high-volume flower plantation. MARIA works in t warehouse — an immense hangar with a high roof and about eighty workers all in blue jumpsuits. There are flowers everywhere - bundles of reds, yellows, oranges, and viole The whole place is a hive of activity: some workers guide large carts on a rail-system into the warehouse; some mea and classify the roses into bundles; some place the bundl in large boxes for shipment abroad. It is a tightly regimented operation. Maria wears thick rubber gloves and stands in front of a splintering plywood board. Next to her is a huge bunch of 100 red roses. One by one, she takes the roses, examines quality of the buds, measures the length, and then with a quick, violent jerk she pulls them over an open blade to strip off the thorns. It's a tedious, repetitive action. She is one in a line of twenty people doing the same work She catches a thorn in her thumb and stops to examine it through the hole in the tip of her glove. Her skin is dot with thorn scars. She’s sweating profusely and she wipes forehead with her sleeve. A SUPERVISOR walks from station to station tallying each worker's output on a clipboard. In another aisle, about twenty feet away, Blanca has the of bundling roses. She sets down corrugated paper and the one by one carefully arranges and wraps the flowers, stap the bundle shut and labels it - then starts all over agai Maria stares at the supervisor, who is now several statio up. She has paused in her work again and is watching everything else in the room with a removed, critical star She continues to perspire and looks physically ill. She raises her hand, trying to get her supervisor’s attention (CONTINUED)
As the supervisor happens to look up he sees Maria's hand the air, sighs and makes his way back to her.
What is it?
Can I go to the bathroom?
Again?
I don't feel well.
You've already been twice this morning. You're under by four bins this hour, three last hour. How are you going to catch up if you keep going to the bathroom? He stares at her expectantly.
Please. I'll be quick.

Do you know what it's like for me always having to look over your shoulder, Maria? You think it's fun for me? I have eighty- four workers in this section and everyone else puts their head down and does their job. But with you, it's like this constant game of tug-of-war just to get you to make quota. At this point, I... All of the sudden Maria VOMITS directly on the flowers, splattering her supervisor slightly.
What the hell is wrong with you?! This is disgusting. Look at this. What the hell? Maria doesn’t dare look up at him.
Look at these flowers. What are you gonna do about these? Huh? What are you gonna do? She just stares at the flowers blankly. (CONTINUED)
(exasperated) Pick those up. Maria scoops up the bundle of flowers in her arms - vomit all. With Blanca and the rest watching, the supervisor le her over to a large BASIN.

Set them there. Maria sets the flowers on a cart. He picks up a HOSE with spray nozzle and twists it until it shoots a fine mist. SUPERVISOR (cont'd) (passing her the hose) Wash them off. Maria picks up a rose and sprays it off.
Be careful with the bud.
But they're already ruined.
I don’t care. Wash them.
I need to go to the bathroom.

(really pissed) You want to go to the bathroom, then you can go on your lunch break... Or you can go right now and keep walking out the door. (he stares her down) I want all these flowers clean. And when you're done, you’re gonna go back to your station and make up the bins you owe me. Understood? The supervisor marches off, leaving Maria there - fuming. EXT. TOWN, STREETS — DAY Maria sits on a park bench and picks at her lunch, as a g of kids her age, dressed in school uniforms, passes by. S makes eye contact with one but they move on past. She che the time.  10. EXT. STREET — AFTERNOON In town. Maria walks up the street.

Maria! Maria sees her mother at a small store buying fruits and vegetables. She crosses over to her. Juana pays for the two bags of groceries and puts a few c of change in her pocket. She picks up the bags and the tw of them walk on in silence. INT. PHARMACY — CONTINUOUS It’s a small place with the drugs on the wall behind the counter. Diana watches as a WOMAN removes foil-wrapped TABLETS from a box and counts them out. Juana enters, trailed by Maria.
Is everything OK?
It’s 9,600. Do you have any money?
(to Maria) Lend your sister the money.
Why do I have to pay for it?
It’s for Pacho. He started vomiting.
So? Where’s your money?
Maria!
I give up practically all of what I make and Diana doesn’t put in any of hers. And now I’m supposed to pay for Pacho’s medicine too? (CONTINUED)

Maria don’t start! Give your sister the money. Juana glares at her daughter. Maria finally digs into her pocket and hands over the money. JUANA (cont'd) You can keep the extra nine-thousand six- hundred when you get paid at the end of the month. I don’t know why everything always has to be so difficult with you. Maria watches Diana pay. And then, as if trying to get ba at them, she says,
Well, there’s not going to be a next paycheck... Because I quit.
What? When?
Today.
What happened?
They wouldn’t let me go to the bathroom.
At all?
It’s not just that. I don’t like the way they treat me. So I quit.
What are you going to do? The woman behind the counter looks very uncomfortable.
You're really fucking stupid.
Why don’t you shut up.
Don’t tell me to shut up! (CONTINUED)
With that, 12. (2)
You don’t know how they treated me.
You could have put up with it. You’re an idiot...
(overlapping) Why do I have to put up with it? Why am I always the one to put up with it all?
(overlapping) ...Why don’t you think of the family for once.
Enough! Quiet, both of you! (beat) Maria, you have to go back and ask for your job back.
No. I’m not going back.
Then what are you going to do?
I’1l find something else.
There’s nothing but flowers around here. At least it’s a decent job.
Oh please, what’s decent about it?
Maria! You have to go back!

Didn't you hear me? I’m not going back... I’m not! Maria storms out of the pharmacy and leaves them standing there.  13. EXT. PLAZA — EARLY EVENING Maria sits by the plaza fountain with Juan and Blanca and group of about five other girls and guys crowded around. Juan's got a BOTTLE of aguardiente and everyone is laughi except Maria, who hasn’t shaken her bad mood.
(laughing) You should have seen the look on the supervisor’s face... He was completely covered in it...
This deserves a toast. Juan pours a shot for Maria in a little plastic cup.
To Maria! Because she kicks ass! She sips it, winces and then swallows the rest in one gul

EXT. OUTDOOR FIESTA — NIGHT A small rocket whizzes into the air and EXPLODES. On a si street off the plaza, there’s a small fiesta going on - w a little band of a dozen local guys (in uniform) playing slightly sloppy, but very energetic salsa - and a crowd o about forty people of all ages - some dancing, some watch Maria and Blanca dance up a storm together - Maria dancin lead. She’s a very good dancer, very lively and quite sex Most of all, she just has a good time - giggling and laug with Blanca. Juan and the guys are sitting on the curb working their way steadily through the bottle of aguardie The music stops and all the dancers fan themselves off - walks among the band members pouring each a shot of liquo
(to Blanca) Hey there’s your boyfriend. Blanca follows Maria’s gaze and sees the SMILING GUY from work talking with a FRIEND. Sure enough, he makes eye contact with Blanca and smiles. (CONTINUED)
(giggling and turning away) Oh my god.
You have to dance with him.
No way! Hearing that, Maria grabs Blanca’s wrist and leads her ri over to the Smiling Guy and his Friend.
Hi.
Hi.
I’m Maria. This is Blanca.
(beet red) Oh my god.
I’m Felipe. This is my cousin Franklin.
Hi. Unlike Felipe, Franklin is dressed stylishly, with a hip shirt, designer jeans and a gold chain. Next to him, Feli looks downright meek.
Blanca wants you to ask her to dance.
Go for it.
(smiling) Do you want to dance?
Felipe leads Blanca out into the dance area as the band strikes up. Maria watches them dance and then walks over Juan. (CONTINUED)

Juan, I want to dance. Juan is clearly too drunk to dance and more interested in guy friends. He takes her in his arms and mock dances drunkenly in a circle, laughing. She breaks away annoyed. MARIA (cont'd) What’s wrong with you?
(drunk) What... why? She walks away and stands watching Blanca and Felipe.
(out of nowhere) Wanna dance? Maria considers it, glances toward Juan... FRANKLIN (cont'd) What do you say?

...Sure. Franklin leads her out and the two of them dance. The mor she dances, the more into it Maria gets - looking over at Juan occasionally - as if she were dancing to spite him. EXT. TOWN — DAY Maria walks the dirt road down the hill and into town. She walks by several store fronts, looking occasionally inside. Her gait is slow and not particularly determined. INT. MUSIC SHOP — DAY Maria steps into a small music shop - basically just a gl case with various CD’s, and racks full of cassettes on ei wall. A MAN catalogues boxes of music as Latin rap plays a small stereo. He nods at Maria - they seem to recognize each other. She takes a tape off the wall and examines it
How much is it? (CONTINUED)
(turns the music down) Fifteen thousand, two hundred. Maria puts it back on the wall. She watches the man work.
You have a lot of work.

I have to catalogue everything, keep track of what I sold, what I didn’t. Maria contemplates asking him for a job... but the store obviously a one-man operation. INT. CHURCH — DAY Maria comes into the Catholic CHURCH where a couple of ol women talk quietly in the pews. She kneels down, crosses herself, mutters a Hail Mary, and then adds her own, sile request. EXT. MOTORBIKE REPAIR SHOP — LATER Maria and Blanca walk up to an outdoor garage that is pac with mopeds and motorcycles. JUAN is squatting next to a mechanic watching him work.
Juan.
(looks up) In a minute.

Come on. (to Blanca) I’1l see you later. Blanca kisses Maria’s cheek and leaves as Juan finally crosses to the front and gets his bicycle. He and Maria cross the street to... EXT. SAUSAGE STAND / PARK — LATER A small stand serving arepas across from a park. Maria an Juan each take an arepa and a Coca-cola. Juan pays and ta the change. (CONTINUED)

They walk over to the park and sit on the grass and eat. They don’t have any conversation at all while they eat - just chew in silence. At a certain point Maria stops and watches Juan take another bite - he’s absorbed in chewing
I have something to tell you.
What?
...-I think I’m pregnant. He looks at her.
You’re not fucking with me, right?
I missed my last two periods and I’ve been feeling sick.
What are you going to do?
I don’t know.
Who else knows?
Only you.
No-one else?
Who else do you think I told? The whole world?
I don't know. Maybe Blanca, since she seems to know everything before me...
(cutting him off) No Juan, Blanca doesn’t know. Long silence... Very long silence. (CONTINUED)
Maria... Do you want to get married?
(laughs nervously) Are you joking?
Why?
Where would we live?
In my house. Where else?
There are like ten people living in your house. You share your bedroom with your brother.
What do you suggest?
My house would be better.
Right, a lot better! A guy living in his girlfriend’s house? No way, not that Maria.
You're really fucking stupid, you know that?

Stupid? Your family hates me. How do you expect me to live there? We can live at my house. (beat) I don’t see why you don’t want to get married. I’m stepping up to this... Maria takes a beat - stares at him.
Juan, do you love me?
(groans) Not this again. (CONTINUED)

Look me in the eye and tell me you love me... What kind of person are you? You want to marry a woman you don’t love? A woman who doesn’t love you? What kind of marriage is that? How long’s it gonna be before you're sleeping with some other girl? A month?
You know that’s not gonna happen.
I don’t want the same thing to happen to me that happened to my sister.
(attacking) I hate to break it to you but your sister was a fucking idiot who slept with the first guy that walked by...
Shut up!
.-.and left her with a kid.
You can’t talk about my sister like that.
You know I’m not going anywhere.
That doesn’t change anything. I’m not Marrying you.
Well you’re gonna have to.
No, Juan. I don’t have to do anything.
See how you are? You’re stubborn.
And you're an idiot. A loser. (beat) I’m not even in love with you. (CONTINUED)
...Me neither.

(stares at him) Perfect. Maria gets up and walks off through the park. INT. MARIA'S BEDROOM — MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT Maria sits up in bed playing with one of Pacho’s stuffed animals. She rolls on her side and stares over at her sister, asleep with Pacho. Maria grips at her sheet - ang frustrated, frightened. EXT. STREET IN TOWN — DAY Maria waits at a BUS STOP with three or four WOMEN. FRANKLIN rides by - they make eye contact - he makes a U- and pulls up on his motorcycle.
Hi.
Hi.
Where are you going?
To the city.
Hop on. I'll give you a ride.
To Bogota?

Sure. Maria gets on and puts her arms around Franklin's waist.  21. EXT. MOVING MOTORCYCLE — CONTINUOUS Maria and Franklin ride through the streets. The scenery changes as they go from the center of town and then into expanse of open country. Taking curves faster and faster. Maria is clearly getting a rush being on the back of Franklin's motorcycle, the wind in her face.
At a juice stand by the side of the road, the girl behind counter scoops fruit into a blender.
I like the way you dance.
Really? You too.
I didn’t think people around here could dance. I thought they were all stiff.
...Where are you from?
I’m from a little town called Santa Rosa de Cabal. About ten minutes from Pereira. You know it?
No.
They have some great hot springs there. I’'1l take you sometime.
Yeah? Franklin flashes her a smile. Maria looks away, blushing. MARIA (cont'd) (beat) So why are you here?
...Various reasons. (CONTINUED)

The girl sets down two glasses of juice. Franklin takes h and walks toward the little tables on the grass behind th stand. Maria follows. FRANKLIN (cont'd) ...It was nothing. I just had to get away for a while. I had some problems and things started heating up. As soon as it all calms down I’m going back... (beat) .--SO, what are you going to Bogota for?
I have a friend who works there. She works for this rich family, in their house. She’s gonna help me out getting a job. Franklin begins to laugh.
Don’t laugh.
I’m sorry... It’s just that you’re way too pretty to be working as a maid. Way too cute to be getting dressed up in a hat and apron. Those people’ll treat you like shit.
(defensive) ..-Anyway, I was just gonna check it out. It wasn’t definite. She moves away from him - sits at one of the little table
(studies her, sits) You lost your job at the plantation, right?
Who told you?
...-Felipe...
That's a lie. They didn’t fire me.
Oh no? (CONTINUED)
You've got bad information. They didn’t fire me - I walked.
(beat) Listen, if you’re looking for work I might be able to hook you up...
Hook me up?
It just depends how bad you need the money. I know of a good job... Traveling...
Traveling where?
To the United States.
What's the job?

(beat) Working as a mule... You know what a mule is, or not? Maria looks away. She clearly knows. FRANKLIN (cont'd) It’s a cool job. You go, hand off the stuff, get your cash. And that’s it... Like winning the lottery.
Yeah, but it’s dangerous, right?
How many mules do you know?
Me? None.
Well, I know a bunch. (CONTINUED)
What about the ones on the news? The ones in prison far away. What about them?
(laughs) Those are the ones who want to be famous. They get caught, get on TV, everyone sees them and they become famous.
(doesn’t laugh) Well I don’t want to be famous.

I know a guy who can set it all up. Takes care of the papers, makes the arrangements... Maria looks away - nervous. Franklin reads her immediatel FRANKLIN (cont'd) You know what - forget about it. (stands) Let's go. He starts to walk toward his motorcycle. Maria hesitates.
Wait. (he turns) ...How much would I get? Hold on Maria.

Bogota is loud and chaotic - buses clog the streets, horn blare, waves of people crowd the sidewalks. With Maria’s arms around his waist Franklin weaves in and of city traffic and pulls up in front of a bar on a sidestreet in an uncertain neighborhood. INT. BAR — DAY It's a dimly-lit place with a pool table at the back and tables along the wall opposite the bar. It’s filled almos entirely with MEN, all older. Maria looks rather uncomfortable as she follows Franklin in. (CONTINUED)

You want something to drink...? (to the bartender) Give me a beer and a soda for her... (to Maria) I’m gonna talk to this guy. I'’11 just be a minute. He leaves Maria at the bar and heads to the back table wh a MAN sits with the only other WOMAN in the place. Frankl shakes the man's hand and points to Maria. Maria sips her soda. Franklin comes back over and waits with Maria. A moment later, the woman at the far table gets up. She makes very definite eye contact with Maria as she walks out.

Come on. Franklin introduces Maria to JAVIER, a well-groomed man o about 60 with a gold chain, an ironed shirt and a cane leaning up against the table. He effects an incredibly paternal tone, calming but also intimidating.
Sit down. Maria sits opposite him. Franklin pulls up a third chair. JAVIER (cont'd) So, you're a friend of Franklin’s. And how do you know each other? Maria falters - looks to Franklin.
(jumping in) She's a friend of the family. On my cousin’s side.
Uh huh... And you’re looking for work?
Yes, sir.
Since when?
About two weeks. (CONTINUED)
And where were you working before?
In a flower plantation.
What happened?
I didn't get along with my boss... so I left.
Rebellious then?
No, sir.
You don’t have a problem taking directions, orders?
No.
Do you get scared easily?
How old are you?
Eighteen.
Boyfriend?
(hesitates) No.
Yes or no? He looks at Franklin.
No. (CONTINUED)
And how’s your system?
My system?
I mean how’s your stomach? Do you have problems with diarrhea, constipation, digestive problems?
No, sir.
Do you eat a lot?
Normal. Javier takes a beat. Examines her. Maria doesn’t flinch.

Well then... We’re going to give you several rolls of film. We’1ll send you to New York... Actually to New Jersey - a small town next to New York. Once you go through Customs you'll be met by our people. They will take you to a safe place. We'll develop the rolls. And in five, six days you'll be back here with all your money taking care of your problems.
How much do I get?

We’1l give you a hundred dollars a roll. A girl your size you could make five or six thousand depending on how much you carry. Keep in mind we have to take care of your documents. Meaning that after we deduct the expenses for your passport and visa and the other papers you'll get about seven or eight million pesos.
(hesitates) What if I get caught? (CONTINUED)

And why would you get caught? Unless you get off the plane trembling like a leaf. Then they’1l catch you. Obviously. But no worries. Those gringos don’t know a thing. (leans in) But once your decision is made there’s no turning back. You can’t tell anyone. Understand? Javier stares hard at Maria.
Yes, sir.

Now, I know you’re in a difficult situation. And I don’t want you making this decision under any kind of pressure. (reaching into his pocket) So I want to give you this so you can take care of a few things... He slides several BILLS across the table.
(eyes the money) ..-No, really it’s not necessary.

(studies her) ..-No, no, no. No strings attached. Maria stares at the money on the table. EXT. STREET / BUS STOP — LATER Maria walks across the busy street and stops at the bus s Among the people waiting for the bus, Maria recognizes th WOMAN who was sitting at Javier's table in the bar. A mom later the BUS rolls up and they all get on. INT. BUS — CONTINUOUS Maria sees a free seat next to the WOMAN. She sits. The woman recognizes Maria but neither of them says anything. (CONTINUED)
You were in the bar, right? (no response) My name is Maria. The woman glances at Maria, then looks away.
I’m Lucy. LUCY looks to be about 24. She's dressed nicely — not fan just more stylish than Maria. But from the way she carrie herself and talks she's clearly from the same class as Ma
Do you work for Javier...? Is it hard?
(not making eye contact) It's not easy but it's not too difficult either... How old are you?
Seventeen. I said eighteen, though.

(looks at Maria) You just have to be prepared and know how to do it right. Maria takes this in. INT. MARIA’S HOUSE — DAY Maria comes home. Diana is folding clothes at the table. Maria walks right past her toward the kitchen.
Where have you been?
I went to the city to ask Jessica to find me work.
(following Maria) And?
And nothing. It’s none of your business. (CONTINUED)
Don’t tell me it’s none of my business.
It isn’t.
You didn’t find anything. You’d tell me if you found something... You have to go back to the plantation and ask for your job back.
No, I don’t.
It’s not fair to mom. You know how hard it is for her and now you’re making things even worse.
Get off my back.
(getting emotional) Don’t tell me to get off your fucking back. Pacho got a hundred and six fever today.
He’s your kid.
I know he’s my kid. So?
So, he’s your responsibility.
(yelling) We’re all equal in this house. We all have to pull our weight. You have to get a job.
Well, I already got one.

What job? Cut the shit. Maria stares at Diana. She then reaches into her pocket a pulls out the money Javier gave her. Diana’s eyes widen. Maria peels off a few bills and throws them down. (CONTINUED)

At least I put in my share. Maria storms out of the kitchen and into her room where s flops onto her bed, fuming. She SLAMS the door. EXT. STREET, A NEARBY TOWN — DAY Maria walks up the street in another town, slightly bigge than her own. She knocks on the door of a concrete house slightly nicer than her own. The door opens and it’s LUCY
